descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement for tea in the "Hindustan Times" newspaper, a man and woman can be seen standing beside a boy, who sits at a desk. The boy is reading a book, as the man and woman drink tea. The woman wears a sari with the pallu (loose end of the sari) draped over her head. The man wears a cap on his head.

inscription.text: Nothing else has the same power as

text-en: Indian Tea relieves lassitude and
text-en: Nothing else has the same power as

description-en: On this advertisement for tea in the "Hindustan Times" newspaper, a man and woman can be seen standing beside a boy, who sits at a desk. The boy is reading a book, as the man and woman drink tea. The woman wears a sari with the pallu (loose end of the sari) draped over her head. The man wears a cap on his head. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Advertisements also emphasized tea's ability to deliver alert, energized citizens, free of the "lassitude" that the British commonly attributed to their native subjects, and ready to build the New Indiaâ€”such as the middle-class parents and dutifully studious son depicted in the newspaper advertisement shown in this image. (Philip Lutgendorf) (gs)
